bibl.title: From Taranto to Alexandria.
bibl.note: Sydney, private collection (ex-Mustaki collection). 6 items of South Italian Gnathia pottery. Alexandria, late 4th and early 3rd cent. B.C. Gnathia is the most imported pottery in Early Hellenistic Alexandria. It is not at all unlikely that some of the new Greek population of the city came from Taranto.

bibl.title: Trade, Contact, and the Movement of Peoples in the Eastern Mediterranean. Studies in Honour of J. Basil Hennessy

bibl.seg: GREEN J.R., From Taranto to Alexandria.

Stephen BOURKE and Jean-Paul DESCOEUDRES (Edd.), Trade, Contact, and the Movement of Peoples in the Eastern Mediterranean. Studies in Honour of J. Basil Hennessy = Mediterranean Archaeology. Supplement 3 (Sydney, 1995) pp. 271-274, 6 figg. et pl. 18.

Sydney, private collection (ex-Mustaki collection). 6 items of South Italian Gnathia pottery. Alexandria, late 4th and early 3rd cent. B.C. Gnathia is the most imported pottery in Early Hellenistic Alexandria. It is not at all unlikely that some of the new Greek population of the city came from Taranto.
